cons: Banner is a huge organization and it definitely feels that way. Lots of red tape to cut through to get anything done. Nothing happens fast. review_title: Banner Home Health management is terrible.
pros: There are some really good clinicians there (RN's, PT's, etc) that truly care about their patient.
cons: I worked there for approx 8 months. Over that course of time 1/2 of my monthly earned PTO was used for low census. Not all of this was due to low census. A good portion of it was due to poor logistical planning and distribution of resources by upper management.. and I paid (myself) the price. Banner cites core behaviors such as: teamwork, communication, ownership, etc. However, they just cite it. For each of their "core behaviors" they pride themselves on I could cite multiple examples of the opposite exhibited by management, coworkers, etc. Also there are many employees that do as little as possible during their home visit. How exactly is a PT supposed to accomplish anything or demonstrate patient care when they are at the patient house for 21 minutes? Banner likes these employees though. If Banner offered me $150k/yr I still would not go back to work for them! They are THE WORST organization I have ever worked for!

pros: My work family is an amazing group of people, not just those in my department but througought the facility.  We managed to pull one another along and make it through our shifts.  If it was not for the "lug nuts" that keep the wheels on "Banners Bus" moving it would be a dismal place to work.
cons: Senior management.  Forcing us to see so many patients that by the end of the shift I can't remember what they look like.  Spending money on motion detectors in break-rooms, really?  Censoring what we say to eachother about our working conditions, do not I repeat Do Not utter the words "unsafe" you will be labeled at problem maker and written up for unfounded reasons.  In Peter S. Fines internal message to employees he stated that we need to provide excellent care to our insured patients as we want them to return, how are we suppose to treat those with no insurance, is Banner going to come up with a way to identify them for us, so we can treat patients selectively?  We are forced to smile and ride the "Banner Bus", as they are quickly becoming a monoply.  Don't ask questions, don't raise concerns about patient safety, don't call in sick, don't use FMLA, don't complain, just work, work work, with less staff and no support.

review_title: Very stressful working environment!!! You'll be sorry if you work here!
pros: Pay is pretty good compared to other comparable jobs.
cons: Management is terrible! They tell you that they have an "open door" policy, but when you come to them with problems, it reflects on you. They will write you up for anything - especially if a co-worker doesn't like you. Management plays favorites (especially in Human Resources). They will allow one person to harass the whole department with no retribution.  Morale is very low. They want you to shut up and not complain and just be happy you have a job. No matter what I did, I could never make my director happy! After 4 plus years, I walked out.  How sad is it to have to work in this kind of environment! No more!!

pros: The colleagues are nice and somewhat helpful and the facilities are modern, clean, and fairly upscale with decent options for employee parking and lots of options for self education through online modules.
cons:
Pay is low, benefits are expensive and not that great, hitting process is a huge time suck and when they make mistakes with your schedule it's on you. They don't care how much of your time they waste. 

They are often understaffed and when they are ever overstaffed they may send you home last minute with either no pay or the option to use PTO which is a cumulative amount of time accrued at a rate of approx one shift per month if working full time. This is for everything including sick time and vacation time. So if you get sent home say 3 times in a month which is the average for new nurses here, then you can only get paid one of those days and you have nothing left for sick time or vacation. It's a terrible system. Also you get no breaks unless you work 12+ hours then you get 30 min unpaid total. You are lucky to be able to take a snack break after 8-10 hours but often no time for any break. And you will often work beyond your scheduled 12.5 hours but won't get paid for overtime until you reach 41 hours.

pros: Having been with Banner 16 years I had many more positive experiences than negative.  When working the bedside I had superb leadership by the one and only Char Leoni.   Patients were truly at the center of all that we could do as nurses.  I appreciated leadership and their guidance and understanding and desire to provide for the patients and the staff.  I felt a sense of family with my peers and we all worked for the patients.  This was at BBMC
cons: Banner got to”Big”.  The vision was lost.  The number one con was that nothing happened fast.  Change had to go through 20 different committees or meetings before any movement or change could take place.  Because of this you have many facilities going “rogue”. Implementing change on their own which unfortunately doesn’t translate to change for the system.   The sense of family is gone and while “Sofia” is what everyone strives for it is hard to see when Banner is always pushing budget and numbers.

pros: Benefits, team work, organized, large company, easy transfers
cons: Low pay, benefit cost increased

pros: THE PAY IS GREAT.

This job is very boring. It is worse than telemarketing. You can literally be replaced my machines, robots, children or even monkeys- as long as training is provided to them.  Any medical information you may need to relay to members can be easily obtained from WebMD, MCG or CMS. 

You are promised tons of opportunity as they do like to promote from within BUT it is corporate, so it is like a glass ceiling as in you will only go as far as THEY ALLOW YOU TO. 

The benefits they boasted about during their interview and on their job postings conveniently eliminate the fact you must be there 6 months for the tuition reimbursement, an application must be filled out and your department must agree to the reimbursement; the health benefits (in Arizona, at least), are approximately $570/month for my 2 children, spouse and myself. 

If you can find another job that matches the Banner pay, than go for that.

review_title: Senior Management doesn't walk the talk.
pros: Some mid-level managers really care about their employees.
cons: The PTO is really awful, although this is my first hospital organization I've worked in.  The salaries are also lower than other industries I've worked in.  There are too few promotion opportunties.  There's too much of a dichotomy between day shift and night shift.  Staff members are not respected equally.  The doctors are not being held accountable for their bad behavior.

pros: good benefits, fairly good pay, some good co workers
cons: Worst place I've ever seen in over 40 years of health industry employment as far as middle and upper management.  They're incompetent, rude and poor communicators.  They don't care about patient care, only how they can boost profits to give themselves bonuses.  They don't listen to employee complaints or suggestions and  have ruthless vacation policies.  You can work a 70 hour week with no overtime then they expect you to take some of your limited time off if you work part of a day. They publish great sounding mission statements then ignore them.  They tolerate incompetent workers because it's easier to ignore them rather than improve them or fire them.  They're lax in bill collection and often allow patients to stay in the system without paying when they should be removed, yet they fire  employees key to good patient care and overload others in order to improve profits.

review_title: Banner Health a great place to work...
pros: Great Health vision, and dental plan!  Not as expensive as others that I have worked for in the past.  They offer a decent 401k package and PTO once you get past the 5 year.  They are flexible with your work schedule when you are a salaried employee.  They offer  telecommuting from home! They offer a a lot of opportunity for growth from within the company.  Everyone is nice, friendly and professional.
cons: They make you take Mandatory PTO around the holidays and they do not separate the Sick, Vacation and Holidays they are all lumped into one pool.  They don't offer any training to advance your career or motivate the employee's to move up in the company.  No overtime or comp days offered when working past your 40 hours as a salaried employee.  Goals are unattainable to even get a decent raise.  Banner likes to work with the bare minimum  and don't seem to care about the life work balance at times!

pros: It used to be the people until the corporation took over.  The medical plan is expensive but it's great coverage.  They have an onsite gym and cafe.  They have an onsite coffee shop that sells gourmet coffee.  The facilities are well kept and constantly being updated which is typical in hospitals.
cons: In Greeley it's all about who you know, not what you know.  There are some real bad directors that should be removed.  The pay grades aren't consistent across the regions.  People in AZ are promoted and paid a lot more.  The Greeley IT Directors make up role summaries to fit their friends.  They set the bar very high and require nice to have qualifications.  The AZ IT staff gets praised and promoted for jobs well done not for passing a Microsoft test.

review_title: Toxic environment/Seldom develop or promote from within
pros: Large organization, plenty of room to move around. Great colleagues/intel shared within collaborative team. Some great practitioners and leaders in clinical groups. I had a phenomenal interim director 2 years ago and then they replaced him with an absolute idiot who had zero management experience or superior knowledge of our functional area.
cons: Limited resources, compensation & benefits, and Paid Time Off due to being nonprofit. BEWARE: they offer PTO and then require you to use those hours for holiday time off (incl corporate holidays like the day after Thanksgiving). Zero tools and resources for employee development from staff RN up to Director level. Managers and Directors are hired with less education than their staff and therefore have no credibility when they need to lead a team. Zero cross functional collaboration.

review_title: Horrible Leadership, communication, and unequal treatment.
job_title: Human Resources and Talent Acquisition in Phoenix, AZ
pros: If you have a friend that is "connected" with the inside political circles you are in for an amazing job. Corporate jobs are fairly easy due to poor organization and work ethic. Large company with a big reputation.
cons: Extremely political and biased leaders. Favoritism is prevalent and rampant including the HR department. They use unfair hiring practices giving some candidates extra help or opportunity during the hiring process while leaving others out. The Talent Acquisition department also makes cases and goals to target certain individuals who they dislike or pose objections. Whistleblowing to HR only paints a target on you. A corrupt system lead by the front lines in the TA and HR departments. Banner also has one of the lowest pay rates in Phoenix and they continue to change your job duties and add more to your workload.

review_title: Banner: not a bad place to earn a paycheck from
job_title: Human Resources Director  in Phoenix, AZ
pros: They truly care about patient care and, to some extent, employee engagement.  There is opportunity to grow and to learn.  There are a lot of smart, caring people working there and it's a pleasure to work with them.  Also, I felt it was a reputablee company that I felt pretty good about working at.  It was my first foray into the healthcare industry and I'm definitely sold on making healthcare a career for the duration.  It has its challenges but certainly has its rewards.
cons: Now that I'm out, I see that it's really not that  bad.   One thing they're bad at is leadership development.  They put people in management positions before they're ready and their direct reports certainly pay for  it.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Mesa, AZ
pros: No pros for working at Banner Health
cons:
I worked at banner health corporate in mesa Arizona in the call center, POSC and CAS.
It is run like a dictatorship!!!!
There are no breaks only one lunch or dinner.
You can't get up to go to the bathroom without being scrutinized and questioned.
You are constantly brought into meetings and questioned about your metrics; how long you are off the board, how many calls you are picking up?
There are constant queues of 90 to 150 calls waiting with 13 medical centers you answer for, callers wait sometimes 45 to 60 minutes.
There is no such thing as customer service!!!
It is such a stressful environment you have people quitting and being fired constantly, and management just keeps hiring more people, the retention rate is bad.
I have worked in call centers before, and this rates the worst!!!
My advice don't work there, the management doesn't care about the employees.
the computers are always broken down, chairs in disrepair, the carpet is filthy and torn, everything is dirty, housekeeping doesn't come in to clean, and the bathrooms are terrible, no paper towels or soap constantly, it's gross!
Employees do not have their own space and are crammed right next to each other, it is nothing short of a sweat shop.
Upper management squelches any complaints, and human resources does nothing?

review_title: Not a Great Place to Work for HR Professionals
job_title: Human Resources Consultant in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Modern HR structure

Excellent, award-winning patient care fueled by passionate frontline staff and respected nursing leadership

Solid intranet and improvements made to workplace technology 

Modernized dress code
cons:
Ineffective Sr. HR leadership with questionable ethics who lack vision, quality people strategies, and engagement with their own HR team

Little to no development for HR employees

High HR turnover that isn’t properly addressed. No exit interviews, stay interviews, or focus groups were done within HR during my duration at the company or after I resigned. 

No meetings with CHRO or Sr. leadership levels about broader HR-specific employee satisfaction survey results and no communication about actions being taken to improve HR’s employee experience 

Antiquated processes and policies that diminish their pay for performance philosophy and drive away high-performing employees

No quarterly webcasts that educate employees about the company’s performance

Lack of diversity and inclusion programs that address internal biases

Uninvolved CEO. Doesn’t do webcasts for employees or make appearances to show appreciation for people’s work. Most people I spoke to never met him although they’ve worked there for years.

pros:
Banner offers a very positive environment to work. As a nurse, the managers are determined to get me the type of assignments I need to improve my skills and grow as a critical care nurse. They frequently take time to ask me how I am liking my position and what my needs are. They encourage each nurse to get certified in their specialty. 

The company itself has great values and actually demonstrates these values with action. The CNO actually enjoys working as a staff nurse occasionally and encourages anyone to call her on her cell for any pertinent reason. It's great to see her enthusiasm.
cons: The only negative, many of my co-workers do have trouble getting the time off they desire. The policies for doing so need some work. However, I'm sure each unit is a little different.

pros: I work in the home care division, so my schedule is a bit more flexible than that of the hospitals. I adore my immediate manager, she goes above and beyond to assist in any way possible.
cons: Benifits are a bit expensive for a family. I feel like I am working just to pay for the benifits. Pay for years of service and experience needs to be higher. I've looked around and found that I could make more at other places based on my level of experience. The work philosophy is great on paper, but the corporation really seems to only care about the bottom line. They say that patient care is first and foremost, but only if it won't hit too deeply in the company's pocket.

review_title: A job to work while you get your feet underneath you
job_title: Medical Equipment Technician in Gilbert, AZ
pros: Good benefits (since you are working for a healthcare company), steady work (if you live in AZ, which is a retirement state).
cons: Salary - Your best bet at getting paid well is to get the best starting salary possible.  After you get hired, any and all wage increases will be negligible, regardless of job performance.  In my case, I had been with the company for a number of years getting "exceeds expectations" on all of my yearly reviews, and got a whopping 35 cent per hour increase.  Meanwhile, a new guy gets hired on (who later winds up being a terrible employee) and his starting wage was $4 more than what I was making after being with the company for several years with exceptional job performance.

review_title: Great Hospital, great care and great people!
pros: Coming from an ICU RN perspective: there is an intensivist program with excellent and kind critical care docs and also an awesome Nurse Practitioner. The other pulmonologists seeing patients at this hospital range from good to excellent. The nephrologists and GI interventionalists are excellent. At night, the unit is covered by icare/EICU MDs and RNs. The ICU utilizes technology that I haven't seen used anywhere else since, such as prone therapy, HFOV. This hospital and ICU is high functioning, and if I was septic, or had respiratory failure, I would feel comfortable with these doctors and nurses treating me, because I feel they are the very best. I am very proud to have begun my nursing career in Del Webb's ICU. Also, it's a non-profit, and invests it's money in the hospital and community.
cons: The year before I left, things were feeling more and more "corporate" as more mandates came down from Banner Health. The time and money squeeze became very apparent and was felt as stress and pressure to staff.

review_title: Beware if your hospital is being bought by Banner
pros: If available to your role there is the option of working remotely. Banner is one of the few companies to successfully role out a work from home option.
cons:
My biggest issue with Banner is their lack of transparency and the trust they ask you to put into them. If you are at a hospital that is being merged with, beware. There will be layoffs every couple of months that will be taken over by their corporate offices.  Don't fall for the false promises that you'll be rewarded if you show you are "flexible" and stick it out.

Banner recently acquired and merged with University of Arizona Health Network - University of Arizona Medical Center. The merge was unique because it formed a new division called Banner University Medicine. Unfortunately, Banner does not have a good understanding of academic medicine. This is causing issues as they try to role out their workflows and systems that might work in a non-academic setting, but does not accommodate the uniqueness of academic medicine. 

Having my entire team outsourced, Banner's lack of meaningful/truthful communication, and Banner's approach to academic medicine is why I am giving the company a poor score.

pros: The location and hours are great.
cons: Lack of communication and lack of vision with management.

review_title: Banner is a good company, but the department I worked in was very unorganized with incompetent management.
job_title: Cashier Culinary and Nutrition Department in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The pay is pretty competitive.  They didn't start me out at the bottom of the pay scale, which was nice.
cons: The one-year transfer policy needs to be changed.  It is impossible to transfer to another position unless you have been in your current position for at least one year.  Supervision was lacking (at least on the shift I worked.)  There was total anarchy.  People would disappear for hours at a time with no repercussions.  Some of these very people, in fact, were promoted to lead positions!  What a joke!  The people who worked hardest were treated badly.  They don't seem to like you if you are educated and have experience.

pros: Most of the team/co-workers are eas to work with, no micro-managing (like other hospitals in the E. Valley), 401k matching
cons: Not the highest hourly/salary paid in a hospital setting (with the majority of depts) when compared to other valley hospitals, so the retention is poor.  The depts are always under-staffed, choosing to make individuals work harder, so corporate can meet their "numbers" to make more money at the top. Insurance offered is too high of a cost for employees.  HR will not fire troubled employees.  Employees have no say in their roles.

review_title: Wisdom and insight from a motivated employee
pros: Flexible work Schedule. Lots of down time to do homework or study when time is managed appropriately. Good foot in the door job. Get to see and observe entire facility. Core employees get discounted meals in cafe. Sheltered parking. Overall great working atmosphere except when you get (Precaution) patients.
cons: Walk about 5-8 miles a shift. Hard to advance from position without a degree. Physical Safety for your position is laxed, you are exposed to numerous pathogens with minimal to no PPE.

pros: This company as a whole has such potential to grow into the most desirable healthcare systems. Progrssive, visionary company. Good Benefits. Opportunites for growth.
cons: With all the new construction, difficult to navagate around facility. There is too much focus on providing a "Spa- like experience" (other than OB) for patients rather than sticking to the business at hand, acute care.

review_title: A good company to work for
pros: Dedicated staff who believe strongly in excellent patient care.  Patient care and patient safety drives all decisions.  A large system enables employees to broaden their skill sets and learn different parts of healthcare.  Each facility/hospital has its own culture. Competitive salaries and benefit packages.  Retention of employees is still a focus despite this economy. A continuous improvement mentality is prevelant in most parts of the organization.
cons: Some highly tenured staff have an entitlement mentality.  When cuts are needed due to budget constraints a small minority of staff pout, instead of understanding that this is a different economy than it was 3 years ago (it seemed to be the highly tenured staff who were the most vocal.)  Lack of a rigorous leadership development program, which is a problem because many leaders are home grown and could really use some revised leadership competencies.  An IT platform that seems antiquated for the size and scope of the company.

job_title: Behavioral Health Registered Burse in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Banner Health has 23 Hospitals and over 35,000 employees in seven states.  Banner Health's focus is on quality care that is fiscally responsible. Patient and staff satisfaction scores are high and trending upward.  The pay for Nurses in AZ is almost double what Nurses make in NC.  Banner University Medical Center - Phoenix is the Flagship Hospital of the System and it is a Magnet and a Teaching Hospital so you get the feeling of cutting edge education, technology and support.  BUMC-P (The former Banner Good Samaritan) Behavioral Health has supportive management.  The staff has decades of experience.  Physicians, managers, the RN's and BHT's are willing to share their knowledge and experience with colleagues and patients.  Overall, this is a great place to work.
cons: Traffic into downtown Phoenix (BUMC-P) is horrible and unpredictable.  Traffic flow moves well around the campus, though.  The aesthetics of most of the hospital common areas are very dated and not family friendly.  Cleanliness, paint, flooring and pharmacy service could all be improved.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Corporate office is centrally located making it an easy commute.  Benefits are less costly than my last employer.
cons:
Non-exempt employees (hourly) have to punch in and out, haven't had to do that in 20 years.  PTO accruals (8 hours a pay period for new hires) include paid holidays, which means employees, specifically Corporate employees must budget for all national holidays like Christmas, Thanksgiving and New Year as well the day after Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve ad New Year's Eve.

The department I work is in a constant state of chaos, there is no planning or process management.  There is no time to do any kind of quality work, there is no elegance.  Turn over is high.

It may be the non-profit nature of the business but there is a "cheapness" to the way Banner Health does business.  Cheapest air fare, cheapest hotels, recycling supplies until they are thread bare or worn out.  Cheapest everything.

review_title: It is hard to staff right now as there are a lack of qualified applicants versus the amount of positions we have open.
job_title: Food Service Worker in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The culture is great! Benefits,.... many of my co-workers are amazing in all departments. " It is hard to staff right now as there are a lack of qualified applicants versus the amount of positions we have open. We want to find great people " Except  food service workers
cons: I was hired into culinary, only because I had a food handlers permit. I had already been hired by 2 behavioral health companies when Banner offered me the food position. I tried for 6 months to get an interview in Behavioral Health with not even a chance. I have heard the term "pigeon holed, Culinary are considered lower quality humans, Mindless work. I have the qualifications, excellent references, and NOW  a new career, in Behavioral Health, with a different company, that knows a quality committed employee after a year and a half with Banner. I am totally insulted and let down by Banner.

review_title: RN to NP in Urgent Care
pros: Large Organization means you wont be fired without warning or reason (except w/ layoffs) and you get paid on time.
cons:
Everything else. 
13.5 hour shifts, NO lunch (NO, I'm not kidding). If there are patients in the lobby you are expected to NOT take a break. You cannot leave for lunch or for ANY reason- including to get new eyeglasses or if you need a tampon. Again, no, I'm not kidding. 
You are expected to see the maximum number of patients, defer charting and then chart from home FOR FREE. 
Holiday pay is a sad 1.25x base. 
NO overtime if you work over 40 hours a week (which is amazing that it is even legal)
"Customer Obsessed" translates to terrible care and entitled patients. 
Awful culture of (rightfully) disgruntled employees. 
Senior management sends out some of the most condescending emails I've ever seen. 
You are expected to NEVER call out. Providers come to work actively vomiting, febrile etc.

job_title: Behavior Health Tech in Tucson, AZ
pros: Scheduling your own shifts, PTO, Benefit Pachage, Coworkers, supportive management, free trainings, exposure to health related accusations if you are in school for any type of Health Sciences.
cons: Upper Management is not very clear about specific matters, must work 4 weekend shifts a month, no hazard pay for having to utilize takedown and suppression methods with clients which become an imminent danger to self or others, first to respond usually act as if security is I the job role but the safety of all patients do fall under responsibilities.

review_title: Overall, good experience until the last two years.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Sun City West, AZ
pros: Good people.  Supportive coworkers.  Everyone helped each other to maintain excellent patient care.  Fair benefits.
cons: Unrealistic patient to nurse/CNA ratios.  Staff spread way too thin. High expectations and little support from upper management.  Disorganized system flow.  Often system changes made without input from the people working in the system, leading to fragmented, broken care systems.  Crony management practices.  Promoting friends in leadership roles  as opposed to those who are most qualified to do the job.  Layered management and administrative staff, making it almost impossible to take care of patients.

pros: I can't think of anything, to be honest.
cons: I'm not sure if it was just my unit or if it happens everywhere on every unit, but this was an absolutely horrifying experience. Employees will backstab each other in order to get closer to the very mediocre and unprofessional managers. I have never worked with a more immature group. There are far too many Chiefs and not enough Indians. People will do anything to climb their corporate ladder and they do it unethically. I hated this place. The CEO was so kind, wonderful, uplifting and inspiring when we did our orientation, but after the orientation, he will not so much as even look in your direction. I said "Hi" to him, at one point, and he just (literally) stuck his nose up to the air. It'd a shame they have bought so many hospitals. I think, because of this, they feel they can treat employees like crap because employees fear they'll never be able to work, again. I was unimpressed. So happy to be gone.

job_title: Support Technician ER in Mesa, AZ
pros: I love my coworkers all the way up to the senior management level. An awesome team to be a part of in a very busy department.
cons: Above senior management: COO's, CFO's, VP's, board of directors, etc., but especially the CEO, are blinded by over inflated salaries, or as they refer to them "compensation" and "bonus rewards". Their obvious focus is not in making healthcare better, nor is it in offering employees adequate "compensation" or "bonus rewards". Their goal is to evaluate reports with numbers and figure out how to get more of those numbers on the reports into their bank accounts. For someone that clears 5 million in a year, he somehow has to find out how to clear 5 million again as if the last 5 mill was blown through already. Meanwhile staff saving lives and actually doing compressions on your loved one so they may have a life get compensated with an "employee appreciation meal" which can't be used to pay bills. Thanks Pete....

pros: Many friendly people depending where you work and quite a few employees that have worked for Banner for years. Working prn is nice for life balance and staffing department employees are  helpful. Good orientation and most employees willing to work together and help each other if needed. Computer systems are user friendly. Good communication  by most and generally a very good work culture. Clean, well maintained facilities and you have the supplies you need to do your job.
cons: There arent always prn shifts to fill. Friendly to your face personality types stick out and unfortunately most of them have a position where they are in charge or have authority over others. There's a lot of competition for a few job openings so you better like staying where you are. If you do get a regular job, its likely a lateral move, except for the hours. Degrees and certifications are everything so forget about your experience- just keep your pocketbook out and forget about any life you thought you had outside of school.

job_title: IT Systems Engineer Consultant in Greeley, CO
pros:
-Banner is a leader in the healthcare field. 
-I had the best manager I've ever had while a IT Systems Engineer at Banner
-Their size allows for interesting and exciting projects to be taken on.
cons:
-I found it difficult to be creative and innovative at Banner (in an IT role), mostly due to policy and regulation (internal and external). I know healthcare is heavily regulated in general, but it just became too much.
-Their size allows for a lot of bureaucracy and slow movement, even though they still want things done fast.

review_title: Everything run by invisible management in Arizona
pros: I work with a lot of great medical professionals. Compensation is good, lots of opportunities for incentive shifts and overtime.
cons: Constantly understaffed. Management changes things on a moment's notice. Expect to float to wherever-adults, peds, ICU, ER, anything-because "a nurse is a nurse" so you're expected to make up for everyone being chronically and dangerously understaffed. Be prepared to defend yourself and your license if you don't feel comfortable with something because you will be put in that position and then you're the jerk for refusing an assignment and stressing out the team. But management doesn't want to have to handle it so they put it on the staff.

review_title: Money may bring them in, we'll see what you do with them.
pros: Given that Banner is the 2nd largest employer here, there is a chance for mobility---unless your boss quashes it.
cons: Top heavy management layers, micro management, disconnect between mission statement and reality, non-competitive salaries for nurses and techs in surgery.

review_title: Spending all of my 16 year career with Banner Health  has helped me to create a strong foundation to grow from
pros: Even though Banner is a large organization with several employees you still feel welcomed and a part of this healthcare family right away.  For the most part the growth of this company has created a positive impact on the health and well-being of the community it serves.  This company has great values and a strong foundation in which any nurse can grow both personally and professionally and advance their nursing practice.
cons: With the increasing acuity and higher census, patients are becoming more and more difficult to take care of.  The turnover rates as a whole are increasing due to nurses getting overworked, underappreciated and burnt out.  There is a also large push for higher education, yet the compensation for tuition is minimal and often difficult to obtain.

pros: Fair Salary; opportunities exist for promotion if you can get past the politics;  facilities are nice.
cons: Bogged down in politics; sluggish HR processes-took several months to complete interview and paperwork and actually begin working many others had similar stories; some very unprofessional behavior among highly educated medical staff- but they get away with it; problems working between departments- work processes are anything but seamless and this causes problems on a daily basis. Medical occupations are inherently demanding and stressful- but the bulk of the stress comes from workplace and staff problems rather than the stress of practicing medicine. Waste due to politics, workplace and procedural issues was rampant-there is a "that's just the way it is" mentality; "watch your back" is common advice amongst the staff.

pros: Large company which includes many great people.  Pay is under the market, but it is a job.
cons: Most of the highest positions are not posted, or only posted after they've chosen who will be getting it.  They tend to only hire people into these positions from the same small circle of yes men/women.  There are then no new ideas, just the same baby boomers congratulating one another on their successes.  In this way, no one will question their processes or want to change things, and will keep telling each other that they're doing a great job.  Reality is that they will continue to be only ever be a hospital company, with its only strengths being the ability to foster fear and an immense lack of conscience towards its employees and patients.  If only the Board knew what was really going on, I can't imagine they'd keep this management team in place.

review_title: Low Pay in High Cost of Living Area
pros: I worked at a facility in Alaska that is no longer affiliated with Banner.  That facility had its own issues separate from Banner.  The good it did provide was some structure to what was originally an independent venture.
cons:
We were being paid Colorado rates (according to local HR).  Colorado, where I lived prior, has a MUCH lower cost of living compared to Alaska.
I was one of two managers in the entire facility that had a Bachelors degree.  Most people had worked there 20 or more years and were completely unqualified for the positions they held.  But since they'd been there so long they got promoted.
Little support for facilities outside of Arizona.  The focus was one growth and capturing as much of the market as possible.  Many of my employees actually made significantly more money than me just because of longevity

review_title: Banner is okay to work for
pros: When I was there the benefits were pretty good.  At first I loved my job then....
cons:
Started out doing mail they kept adding more and more work to my plate so much so that I changed jobs.  They tend to fire/downsize people and never hire a replacement forcing the remaining personnel to do the job of those that have left and their own jobs as well. 

Started out in 2007 they gave a yearly raise of 5% when I quit in 2012 their standards were much higher you had to give 150% to receive a 3% max raise!

I have friends that still work there and the cost of insurance has gone up so high they can not afford it!

review_title: Watch your back or you will be  taken advantage of as a new grad
pros: Good place to start as a new grad,   variety of patients, detailed onboarding process.   Some very experienced RNs work for Banner.  Great learning opportunities are possible on the right unit.
cons: Preceptors ranged from great to poor.  Be careful with anyone who says outright that they're only doing it for the extra money, then shows up late or leaves early.  Manager was never available, had to come in on day off just to meet that person after a number of attempts to speak by phone.  This should have been arranged on day 1. Turnover on some floors continues to be an issue.  Management seemed indifferent to RN concerns about increasing acuity and staffing levels.

review_title: Listen to your staff and evaluate your managers better
pros: The benefits package is a good one. Unfortunately they are unfair in how much their employees have to pay into it depending on whether they work at a clinic or at a hospital. A CNA working at a clinic can barely afford benefits. On the other hand as an RN the price is reasonable for what you get and is comparable to other local institutions.
cons: Management overbearing. They do not listen to the staff and are missing from the frontline of patient care. Managers are allowed to get away with too much and their is no reckoning to the people who actually perform patient care. There needs to be some type of manager evaluation that is done by the staff other than Gallup polls.

review_title: The worst company I have ever worked for!
pros: The stated culture and values sound terrific......to bad they are just word-speak and mean nothing.
cons:
Upper management at Banner are scary people. They dump tons of responsibility on mid-managers and staff, won't listen to anything mid-management has to say, actually they don't even ask, they just play the blame game when things don't go as THEY planned.
Stating facts, such as, "We don't have enough equipment to support that initiative", is considered "negative input" and is not tolerated.
They only want to hear, "yes", even if "no" is the only sane honest response.
Other cons:
Salaried and 10-14 hour days were the norm, on-call every other week end from 7a Sat. until 7a Mon. (no monetary compensation or comp time) AND had to go in every other Sunday for a few hours to do tome cards! I didn't just quit....I escaped!!!

pros:
- Coworkers are nice 
- Good entry level patient care experience
cons:
- Low wages (unless you’re promoted to a Lead, in which case you’ll make 3-4 dollars more than everyone else even though they’re working as hard and as much as you). Underpaid! Everyone is underpaid! We are struggling and sick of it! 

- Harassment! So many stories of harassment and nothing happens. I reported someone for harassing me, they’ve also harassed three or four others and been reported but nothing has been done. Nothing. 

- Poor communication between different areas of the hospital. 

- High turnover. 

- Insurance is overpriced and useless since they switched to Aetna 

- Overworked & understaffed for large periods at a time

- Upper management doesn’t care about food service and we are constantly and consistently overlooked for upgrades, the kitchen is falling apart and nobody seems to care 

- If you like soul-sucking frustration, work at Banner!

pros: Southern Arizona's only Level I Trauma Center, transplant center and academic teaching facility. Professional staff seems to take pride in their work. The job is always interesting.
cons:
Entry-level workers (i.e. patient care technicians, janitorial staff, etc.) do not appear to take pride in their work and their apathy shows. The hospital is just dirty in general and some people act as if they are put out by having to actually work. 

Establishment of "University of Arizona Health Network" seems haphazard and like management is just operating on the fly at this point. $3 million was spent on "rebranding" and the hospital can't even afford to provide the staff new badges.

Hospital expansion, at least in non-direct patient care departments, has resulted in the creation of unnecessary mid-level management positions, where even the existing positions were superfluous. The addition of these positions does not seem to have resulted in noticeable improvement in operations.

review_title: An overall good experience that I would recommend to a friend.
job_title: Medical Laboratory Technician in Mesa, AZ
pros: Banner Health overall is a great place to work for. They have great Medical, Dental, and Vision benefits. Management is very approachable. I think  highly of my manager in particular. Since it is such a large company, your job feels secure and there is always room to move up the career ladder.
cons: Banner Health has a strong corporate mentality. If you are one minute late (six minutes past the clock-in time) you are considered tardy. I have seen quite a few people fired for being tardy too many times. You are also not rewarded for how hard you work, only that you keep your errors low.

pros: Banner Health is the future of Healthcare. Its process improvement methods are thoughtful and thorough. This 35,000 strong organization does all it can to hear the voice of the employee. While not perfect they strive to be industry leaders, with a "Patient's First" attitude.
cons: Banner has had to streamline benefits due to declining reimbursement methodologies. One of the benefits that was important to me was tuition reimbursement. While it is still offered, it is no longer for every employee. It is rare that a non-Rn receives tuition reimbursement. Instead it is tied to the hospitals strategic initiatives, i.e. you must be a nurse pursuing your bachelors because in order to obtain magnet status a certain percentage of employed RNs must have bachelors.

pros: Big company, decent pay and benefits.
cons:
Banner in Fairbanks is toxic.
The administration of the Fairbanks hospital, managed by Banner is a "good old boy" network that requires nurses to violate HIPAA laws and terminates those who object to their micromanagement of clinical departments.  The administrative team repeatedly places "scapegoat" directors into departments that are failing financially secondary to administrative incompetence and then they fire or demote them...with the blessings of Banner AZ.  Given that the Banner run hospital is the only hospital in the area, their treatment of staff is beyond heartless as they through professionals to the curb in an area where there are few healthcare jobs available.  They cannot be trusted to treat the health professional equitably, they are treated based upon the emotions and personal opinions of the bad apples who have made their way into administration.
The citizens of the community are NOT happy with Banner.

pros: Caring nurses and doctors.  Lots of locations. Strong leadership in the hospitals.
cons: Disturbing "slash and burn" RIFs occurring across the company.  Questionable HR practices.  I'm not even sure who is left in that department after they got rid of their experienced HR staff and hired new (cheaper) staff. When I try to find someone to ask a question, it is all new people each time.  The woman who runs HR is a ruthless thug with a fake smile.  Be careful.  If she likes you, you'll be fine.  If not, get your resume ready. Those of us in the facilities are shaking our heads watching the corporate departments and wondering who is left to help us. There is no leadership development offered anymore and we need that more than ever now.  Most of us are working on our resumes. I couldn't recommend a job here to an enemy.

review_title: Thought it was my dream job
pros: Benefit package and 401k are great. Able to choose own schedule to a point. Parking is free and easy.
cons: Lots of bullying, humiliation, and intimidation from other nurses. No one does anything about it. There is a lot of favoritism as well with management. People working there seem depressed and angry and never say hello back. They like to pick on certain people and make their career miserable to the point that people quit or get fired. Unit is very clicky and are not welcoming to new people. Unless you are friends with management there is no advancement for you. Patient assignments are unfairly assigned to the staff. Lots of gossip and jealousy in the unit. They don't like that you ask questions when you are unsure of something.

pros: Bonus eligibility at the end of the year. Flexible schedule in the department I work in.
cons: No accountability of other staff with management, If you work hard and others slack off you are expected to cover there slack. Minimal raises given for going above and beyond. Very little recognition for going to extra mile. Manager has her favorites that are allowed to do whatever. Poor communication from management. Overworked and underpaid for the job assigned. I am assigned more because I have shown I can do more but others on my team have been assigned less because thats what they produce and instead of making them produce more it just gets assigned to others that are performing.

pros: flexible schedule, good coworkers, pto, benefits
cons: turnover increasing because of declining culture.  all about the budget and they have forgotten that if you treat your employee as #1, your employees will pass that down to the patients. corporate has NO idea what is needed on the floor , there is a huge disconnect between upper management and floor staff. Banner used to be the place to work but over the past 5 years they have lost that reputation amongst nursing staff. Nursing education has been weeded out. Very corporate now,feels like a for profit environment.

review_title: Pharmacy is in poor shape, but there may be hope
pros: The staff work really hard as it is a very high paced environment.  There is little oversight, but mostly self-driven individuals keep the department running fairly safely through disasters despite poor management.
cons: The current management is seeking employment elsewhere after poorly managing for several years, but hopefully replacements will improve the state of things.  The current incentive system rewards lazy, selfish workers while people that actually work for improving the department are actually discouraged either through lack of support or lack of recognition.  There is a lack of the sense of team in the department, it is very segmented and current management seems to make things worse by pitting staff members against each other and removing themselves from staff.  There is no human connection as they strive to make the department feel like a corporation.

pros: Good benefit options with multiple choices, 401 k match, work from home opportunities.
cons: Poor direction from upper management, lack of cross team communication, bonuses paid to doctors and upper management only, no formal training process for new hires, lack of ability to move teams internally without taking a position downgrade and cut in pay, yearly raises that don't exceed yearly inflation increases, biased against employees outside of Phoenix area.

pros: Middle management truly knows what the staff is going through, and try their best to help staff.
cons: Middle management tries so hard to walk the tightrope that senior management has them walking. Senior management is so removed from what actually happens "on the floor" that they make knee jerk reactions and all the while they are congratulating themselves on what a great job they do. Banner Health 5 years ago was still a great company to work for. It is now such a joke and so many are looking for jobs elsewhere. Their retention has taken a huge hit this year. I work in a dept. that almost everyone is unhappy about, yet the CEO, and the CNO are clueless.

pros: Reviews based upon performance.  Culture was sincere, positive, forward thinking and a great experience.  Did not feel threatened that others were out to get you or disprove you.    Great teamwork and collaboration among staff at all levels of the organization.  Really focused on patient care and clinical outcomes.  Great medical benefits and PTO accumulation.
cons: Silently letting people go, a little at a time as to not draw attention.  Once your on this "list" it's pretty impossible to be retained---multiple internal interviews where well qualified, but no one would take these folks.   This happened quite a bit with long term employees >14 year many over 20.

pros: Banner provides excellent resources to help leaders be successful in their position including a 5 day "new leader experience." Banner promotes individual growth within the system and truly appears to value the voice of the staff and leader as evidence by annual voice surveys that are used to gage staff engagement and overall happiness with Banner as an employer.
cons: While Banner does have great resources to assist leaders and staff the enormous amount of work is not feasible to maintain. Average week for a Banner leader is in excess of 65 to 70 hours. Work life balance is not feasible resulting in leader burnout. Frequent change in leadership is noted as a direct result.

pros: You at least have a job.
cons: Managers are back stabbing and do what saves their position and numbers. If you are liked you can change your schedule all the time. If not you can wait for a year or more and then they will hire a new person and give them the position you have been waiting on. They don’t follow policies unless it suits them. If you voice your concerns, you put a target on your back. They admit to not wanting to pay more. Longer you stay the less benefits and time off you get. Surgeons can act out, scream, verbally abuse you and it is allowed.

pros:
There are some really good people here
Benefits are decent, still expensive
My supervisor was very flexible with scheduling
Good PTO once you’ve been there a few years
You can’t be fired once you pass your probationary period
cons:
I was harassed and berated constantly by my department’s leader
Pay is significantly less that equivalent positions in comparable companies
Data/System/Process silos wreak havoc in daily operations
“Leadership” is a joke
You have to work with people who can’t/won’t do their jobs
You’re a number to the organization. There is very little respect for the individual

job_title: PFS Representative/Physician Practice in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great entry level position, especially for someone new to the area, and looking to get local experience. People were friendly.
cons: Full-time salary was considerably less than temp/registry salary. In addition, have to pay a large amount out of pocket for benefits even though they sell it as their "total package".  Management really not present, and mostly always concerned with how much money we were collecting from patients.  Was told collections were always below average even though we consistently collected above and beyond. Very little room for advancement - you have to be part of the "inner circle" to get ahead.

review_title: They are always concerned with the bottom dollar, more than their employees.
pros: We were able to purchase good health insurance.
cons: They sold the AZ and CO Urgent Cares to two AZ  Banner doctors who terminated all Banner Urgent Care Employees. It affected hundreds of people. We all had our work families broken apart. A very sad deal. The are staffing with all new employees as no one who was terminated wanted to work for them. They also decided that their business model would not include any Registered Nurses, but have just a medical assistant to take care of patients. This is a liability in the making. We provided such a great service to the community. It is such a loss for us and the community.

job_title: Executive Director RN in Greeley, CO
pros:
Highly matrixed Healthcare organization that is progressive in addressing and responding to the rapid changes in healthcare. 
Offer lots of internal growth opportunities and located in 7 states. 
Non-union environment allows leaders to have a very collaborative working relationship with their employees and they support a shared leadership model.
cons: You must be prepared for rapid change and job realignment to be successful in leadership in this organization.

review_title: Banner Health focuses on growth, not patients or employees
pros: It's a paycheck for now. A company that is very good at actually designing and building hospitals and clinics. Also very well adapted to a culture of "Silo" management.
cons: Emails from company brass showcase all the synonyms for "reinvent". Banner has no idea yet, how to interact with employees or patients. Banner is unable to model for employees what a professional, friendly, caring interaction should look like with human beings. This leaves employees and patients with a cold, uncaring image of the company. Employees are patients too! The company can build hospitals and clinics., and buy up other health care sectors like urgent care or home health. Just not sure how we can attract patients with commercial insurance, to use our doctors except if they are very acute in their illness or injury.

review_title: Having fun while working at Banner Thunderbird
pros: Seeing other employees enjoying their job..  Walking into work wanting to be there.  Knowing there will be someone to cheer me up and help me when I need it.  Having supportive co-workers and cooperative volunteers.  Patient's needs come first and patients don't always show their appreciation, but working at Banner Thunderbird you are almost guaranteed a word or two of encouragement and support.
cons: Location of the facility is not best.  I don't like parking in the garage especially at night.  The neighborhood is not a safe neighborhood to walk around at night, especially a few blocks south of the hospital.  Patient morale is low due to lack of funds to help support their treatments.

job_title: Professional Individual Contributor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Large Organization with lots of opportunities for growth.
Interesting Work.
Fantastic Co-Workers.
Nice Benefits Package.
Healthcare Innovator.
cons:
Does not have 100% hospitalization within any of its medical plans.

Downward communication has deteriorated over the past year and my department no longer has all they information they need to plan our work accordingly.

review_title: Started great, slowly eroded over the next several years
job_title: RN Case Manager in Mesa, AZ
pros: This was a beautiful facility with competent staff when it opened in 2007. Banner has grown exponentially. A lot of the staff is really wonderful.
cons: The amount of talent (RN and other) that they have wasted is astonishing. Leadership here is truly awful. They try a path, it fails, they fire half the leadership and try something else and then eventually circle back to the first idea...which was a terrible idea from it's inception and was likely arrived at by a firm hired by Banner to came in and tell them what is wrong with their operations.  Even departments with successful meeting of 'targets' and 'initiatives' will eventually get rolled by another Senior leadership decision.

review_title: The employees are great to work with but the senior leaders and executives are not the best.
job_title: Administrative Assistant Senior in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Banner is well known throughout the communities it serves. Most of the employees are there to live the mission of making a difference in people's lives through excellent patient care.
cons: The cost of benefits is too high especially since it's the Healthcare industry. The compensation is low compared to other local Healthcare organizations and annual bonus based on hospital ratings are no longer available to staff but upper management still gets their annual incredibly large bonus and they get unlimited paid time off while other employees have to work almost one month to accrue one day of paid time off.

review_title: Blue box for majority of people
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Big company which means lots of money for equipment and supplies.  Relationships with a lot of doctors.  Biggest employer in Arizona
cons: Does not specialize in majority of areas.  Can take care of 90% of people but if something is unique they can not help the patients.  Providers sometimes will misdirect patients on what an illness is instead of admitting they don't know.  Benefits are getting worse and worse over the years.  Insurance is limited to Banner facilities and covers little if they can not take care of the medical problem.

review_title: No compassion, leadership not interested in employees, just another cog
job_title: Registered Nurse ICU in Glendale, AZ
pros: There were a few employees that support each other, locations close to home. Free parking, sometimes covered.
cons: There are many managers, but no leaders. You are not values as an employee. The management values gossip and undying loyalty, and inflated ego's. There is no culture of professionalism, no compassion from managers. You are just another piece of equipment to them. If they can get someone else cheaper, they will. There  is no concern for employee safety, and if you get injured on the job, it is automatically your fault. No way would I work there with the Ebola virus scare, as they dismiss you for being sick or injured.

job_title: Patient Care Assistant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Staffing ratios are good. Many great people to work with and learn from. Banner also has great training resources.
cons: Recent reduction in employee benefits, i.e., disallowment of ANY degree starts in Jan. or Feb. 2009 --even if it is a nursing degree. I think this is not very wise of management, especially considering all the money wasted on corporate catering and other things that don't contribute to patient care.

job_title: IT Systems Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits, vacation and fair pay.  I always felt like I was part of a good team, getting things done and making a difference.  I really enjoyed the people, and the technology was right on par with the best of the IT shops in the valley.
cons: Too many meetings and not enough work getting done.  It seemed like most leaders would refuse to put their foot down and just move action items to the next meeting.  If they could cut the meetings in half, people would be twice as productive.

review_title: Work Life Balance?  Surely you jest!
pros: Many very nice people who are very pleasant and great to work with from a direct care perspective. We enjoyed a temawork mentality. We had to or the patients would suffer and that is not supposed to happen in healthcare.
cons: Patient care takes a backseat to monetary gain. Staff is overworked, underpaid and then "coached" for having attitude or  tone?  We are pushed to the limit.  We are trying to take care of our patients.  We want to do the right thing and give great care, but we do not have the tools to do our job nor do we have the support.

review_title: Overworked employees, unsafe staffing levels, and an overwhelming need to accumulate property to dominate the valley.
pros: Staff and middle management work hard to meet the needs of the patient. Teamwork is solid.
cons: Understaffed in most all departments. Do more with less attitude, causes missed procedures and errors. C-Suite leaders need to be held accountable for their core behaviors and create a safe environment to express safety concerns without fear of retaliation. Leaders are so busy with meetings that they dont have any time to spend in their own unit.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Mesa, AZ
pros: I love my job as a RN. I work with a great team and I have a passion working in the PCU, Tele, and ICU setting. I have plenty of experience working with Neuro patients and I am ready to pursue my career.
cons: I have no cons working as a registered nurse is a true passion. I am looking to pursue my career as a clinical education specialist. I am working toward a Masters in Nursing education at ASU and I am ready to put my deree to work.

review_title: Constantly short staffed, good teamwork, disonnect with Leadership
pros: Teamwork is what makes this place work.  Benefits are good, and clinical skills make you proud to work amongst the very best.
cons: Extremely short staffed constantly.Senior Leadership, and supervisors just say "make do"! Staffing incentive offered too late in the season to make a difference. Not enough appreciation to keep working yourself to exhaustion. Staff placed in critical care areas with No training, risking licensure, and patient outcomes.

review_title: Great company, great people. True to their mission and motto.
job_title: Financial Analysis Consultant Supervisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Amazing work environment and balance of life and work. 
Good people. 
Procedures in place are designed to help every employee to grow and develop. It practically feels expected; regardless of your job title. 

100% investment vesting after a year. 
4% match
Great for employees looking to start families. 
Remote working options. 
Learning opportunities. 
Regular reviews each quarter.
cons: IT/BI setup seems a little bureaucratic and overkill. The policies feel more inhibitive rather than protective.

pros: I really feel like the best part of my job is the people I get to work with in my department. Banner is headquartered in Arizona, but has facilities in Colorado, Wyoming, etc. As a smaller player in Colorado, we have a smaller famikly feel and our unit camaraderie is great. People get together off work and enjoy the outdoors.
cons: Like a lot of health care organizations, cost seems to be a driver of a lot of decisions.  I understand the business side, but would prefer a bit more long-term vision.

pros: Banner offers good benifits, medical, dental, vision, 401k, ect. The pay is also competitive. They also offer bonuses based on overall patient satisfaction in their hospital system.
cons: PTO system is flawed, everything is combined. Maternity leave is only five week paid. They are not very supportive of breastfeeding mothers. We are forced to were uniforms all of the same color and kind for our profession. Write employees up for smoking on their break period.

review_title: Not a plesent place to work at all.
pros:
Good insurance
Yearly bonus
A lot of PTO hours per pay period
cons:
Very disoragnized company.
Administration is all about themselves and care less about their employees.
Customer service is more important than patient care, and if I wanted customer service I would go to Wal Mart. 
No money for yearly raises, yet they spend all their money on re-paving the roads and refurnishing buildings. 
Very understaffed. 
Not black and white rules. There is a lot of grey areas as to what is expected and what is not.

review_title: On the ball with health care reform
pros: Banner is big on wanting all employees to at least be aware of the business side of healthcare and explaining why they set priorities.
cons: I was able to excel in a small hospital (take on several leadership roles) but it was impossible to break into opportunities within the larger organization.

review_title: Overall Banner is an excellent place to work and I enjoy being part of the company.
pros:
They have the best benefits package (PTO, health, 401k) of any healthcare company that I have worked with in the past 20 years. 
Banner is very large so there are many opportunities for advancement. 
Banner has a VERY strong telecommute program.
cons: Very little room for salary negotiation. - I was only able to successfully negotiate a higher salary on one instance (my initial hire).  Since then I have had 4 promotions without successfully negotiating a higher salary.

pros:
Peer support- team members look after each other (not including management)
Centrally located
Decent benefits
cons:
Poor pay for experience and contribution.
Over run with bullies and “cool kids” cliques.
Management teams full of “bosses”, seriously devoid of any actual “leaders”, or any idea as to what the difference is.
Favoritism- different perks and consequences, depending on how well liked you are, for the same accomplishments or infractions.
Unable to retain qualified and passionate staff, close to 50% of staff within units are new grad and/or inexperienced RNs. Which only serves to decrease job satisfaction, increase burnout, and threaten patient satisfaction and safety.

pros: Generally decent co workers (sometimes), benefits are ok, pay is better than the average for the area
cons: Poor management, department managers allowed to act unchecked by upper management, probation period does not allow for new employees to make mistakes while trying to adjust to an entirely new culture. They can terminate you for ANY reason without any opportunity to correct.

pros: Banner is a healthcare provider so employment in clinical areas is relatively stable. The same cannot be said for support departments.
cons: The company continues to acquire more and more physician offices and hospitals.  The company doesn't have the infrastructure and processes in place to on-board physicians, clinics, employees, etc.  Credentialing of new physicians is a nightmare.  Banner continues to cut "support" services to the point that it's impossible to get anything accomplished.  I've worked here many, many years and have never seen the company in such a disorganized mess.

pros: I worked for Banner for over 26 years in the Western Region and in a system-wide capacity.  It used to be great place to work.  Patient safety, teamwork, standardized practice and employee satisfaction were really valued.
cons: No longer a good company. Poor leadership and lack of insight has really taken its toll. Bringing in outside consultants who know little to nothing about healthcare was a big mistake.  Banner no longer cares about retaining employees. Poor financial planning has impacted sustainability.   The way downsizing and layoffs are handled is bad, and has created morale problems.  Toxic environment in many departments with everyone being asked to do more and more with less and less is made worse by bad managers, and is impacting patient safety.  Banner's motto of "All change, all the time," has contributed to its decline.

pros:
mostly independent work for those who hate the team atmosphere
decent pay for easy work. 
networking opportunities are abundant
cons:
other employees slack off and expect you to do the same.
benefit options have become atrocious and expensive
you are just a shirt not a creative mind do not try to make improvements on processes or procedures already in places 
doctors and nurses treat facility staff like dirt. you are beneath them as a housekeeper, food service worker, supply chain staff, facilities/maintenance staff.

review_title: If all you want is a decent job, then consider Banner Health.
pros: Pretty good benefits, generous time off if you can get it approved. Several locations make it possible to work close to home. An great amount of professional autonomy.
cons: Employees promoted to supervisor with no other qualification than being a friend of the manager. Gallop polls manipulated by harassing employees over poor results. Uneducated and under-qualified employees in the same pay grade as college educated, highly qualified employees.

review_title: Banner doesn't hold employees to a high standard and enforce accountability, pay and incentives aren't there.
pros:
-flexible schedule
-good amount of PTO
cons:
-no raises & poor pay(other nearby hospitals are still getting raises!)
-no retirement! (other nearby hospitals pay retirement plus contribute to 401K)
-no accountability which goes back to management
-overworked & understaffed
-'behind times' as far as equipment & procedures performed
-poor communication
-poor benefits, education, ect..
-Employees are not happy and all want to leave

review_title: Great Health Care - Probably the best hospitals in Arizona
pros: The employees with direct patient care, who have their "feet on the floor" at any of Banner's 30 or so hospitals are almost universally awesome. They care about their patients, and as both a former patient and employee, it was amazing to see that the service they delivered far exceeded my expectations. I will also note that, despite the lack of pay increases and the fact that advancement is based solely on how many years you've worked for the company (which is nearly identical to archaic union-type rules; however, all Banner employees are non-unionized), "base" or introductory bay is quite fair, and in the nursing world, is probably above market pay compared to other cities.
cons: The primary con is that that there's a complete disconnect between the hospitals and corporate management. For the most part, I mean that new corporate policies and rules are put in place by desk-dwellers at the corporate office (occasionally in conduction with the handful of higher level, "desk only" administrator-types at the hospitals). The policies or rules are almost universally designed to save money, and almost universally have a negative effect on employees (example: change from performance-based pay raises and bonuses, to a policy of no raises, or a maximum raise of 1% for the top person in each department). While base pay is pretty good, such practices certainly lower overall morale. It's a double-edged sword, though. The nurses and staff dealing every day with patients may be aggravated by such changes, but they still treat patients in exactly the same way. I'm not saying that they shouldn't, but the company acts as if it knows very well that the high moral fiber and ethics or the medical staff will not change, even if the company slowly takes away fringe benefits (lowering vacation days or PTO calculations), eliminates pay raises, and at times, disempowers employees from bringing forth ideas for real change and improvements. Also, as I mentioned earlier, the only way to increase your pay or get a promotion is to work for the company for a long time. They virtually instill this into the minds of each new hire, and you'll find many employees with "certificates" on their walls, stating that they have worked for the company for 5, or 10, or 15, or 20 years. This is highly reminiscent of unions and almost militaristic. The major downfall to this is that when a higher position opens up, the individual who applies and has the most "time in" with the company, is the person who gets the job. This can result in bizarre scenarios where a mid-manager in an area such as food management is promoted to a corporate desk job managing payroll or IT (without the person having any education or experience in that area).

review_title: Terrible HR policies, dieing network and loosing talent
pros: There are some good people that work in the departments and benefits are about average.
cons: work-life balance is terrible, work on average 50 hours a week on a relatively low salary for the type of job / work I do due to bad HR policies that don't allow pay increase. 4 yr college degree plus additional certifications... Have a terrible manager that HR won't do anything until everyone starts quitting. Benefits used to be a huge pro, that is no longer the case.

pros: The co-workers are great! I love the people I work with inside the OR and even employees outside the OR are so friendly. It's a great place to work if you love the hospital setting. There are also corporate opportunities if you like that side of things.
cons: Theres always cons to every workplace for different resons, for this specific job title I would say the con is that this job is so entry level. If you are looking for a foot in the door this is perfect! But the management is not the greatest unfortunately...

review_title: Preaches core values, but doesn't live by them
job_title: Office Administrative Support in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Lots to keep people busy, various departments and positions to fit the desire of anyone looking to work in healthcare, many hard-working people in the company
cons: View on promoting within, managing finances and taking care of employees way out of whack; more interested in keeping employees stalled in current positions and hiring outsiders, even if less than qualified, spends money on acquiring too many new facilities instead of increasing salaries for loyal employees

job_title: Medical Equipment Tech in Gilbert, AZ
pros: Good place to learn basic DME Tech stuff.  Good Benefits.
cons: DME department can seem unorganized.  Techs are left to make decisions after hours on call regarding if patient qualifies for equipment and insurance coverage. On call 5pm friday straight thru to 8am monday when office opens. So be ready for non stop action. BS calls in middle of night awake at 2am 3am  so on. Some patients never happy. High turnover,  intake always seems stressed out. Not much upward mobility, that is for sure from tech standpoint

pros: Adequate wages  for staff members.
cons: Too much micro managing from the company. I heard many complaints while working there from patients and other staff members.  It was hard to keep a straight face when I knew it was true.   Your years of experience did not really matter to the company, I always felt that they were trying to get rid of the old company's staff in order to bring in new staff in or to pay them less.   Little do they know firsthand, that there are many lawsuits against Banner  That's the public does not know about.   A pretty new face on a hospital does not excuse bad behavior from its staff.

pros: Good co-workers but most of them leaving due to management.
cons:
Poor management. They hire clinical managers that have never worked bedside or are years out of beside nursing. They never help out on the floor. They will walk past call lights going off. They shut themselves in their office while their staff is drowning. Not once have I ever been offered help. They don’t know the answers to simple policy questions. Many of them are moody and have no management skills. Upper management seems totally oblivious or just doesn’t care.  
Staffing  in all departments is poor putting more stress on the bedside nurse.

pros: Banner is a large employer, you can work closer to home.  There is good communication from the top down in terms of changes that are coming.  The administration is visionary and has pulled off enormous sea changes, ie; going to electronic charting, getting most paperwork online, communicating via Email.
cons: Five years ago, this was a much more enjoyable place to work.  Now, it's all about how do we cut costs and wring the most out of each worker.  Benefits cost more and cover less, there are less people for each shift, more call, to cover the more frequent bare spots created by having less people to do the cases.  Call isn't just for the "off hours" anymore, either.  Now, there are TWO people on call for most of the 24 hour cycle.  Three dollars an hour for call pay is almost an insult, I'd rather have control over my own destiny.  The refrain bantied about the department is "according to departmental needs", as you may imagine, this trumps the 'balance of work and home life'.  The whole feel of the place is "Shut up and work, be glad you have a job!".  Our turnover rate is astounding, I'm amazed that no one from the upper echelon is had their curiosity piqued.  The managers are good people who are Way over their heads, and as a group, they lack sophistication in the people handling arena.  The main thrust had been to force fewer people to do more work.  I dread going to work and being micromanaged.  Every week there are more rules and more tasks that make my job harder, and lessen the amount of actual 'nursing' that I get to do.  I am heartsick about it.

review_title: If it isn't in writing, it doesn't exist!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sun City, AZ
pros: With the growth in the health care industry, employment opportunities with Banner Health will continue to expand.
cons: Only believe what you have in writing.  Prior to the our 'merge' with Banner Health, we were told coverage for sick days would be 100%.  Less than six months after the 'merge', the coverage dropped to 67%.  While employees with pre-merge Extended Sick Leave (ESL) hours left in their accounts could fill in the gap, new hires had to bite the bullet.

review_title: Good healthcare system but not that great to their employees
pros:
Many facilities. This is a big pro. Many opportunities within the Banner network due to the vast amount of facilities.

Management opportunities 

Very focused on patient satisfaction.

Great co-workers

Supportive front line management (varies from department to department)

Caring staff 

Modern facilities

Latest technology (e-ICU, medication scanning, total electronic charting...)
cons:
Inadequate staffing (over the years, Banner has continuously decreased support staff, and the patient acuity is higher then ever. In some facilities, they have even raised the patient to nurse ratios making the work load unmanageable).

Uncaring upper management (Varies from facility to facility)

Tuition reimbursement only given to some employees. Not a true benefit. Anyone can apply for tuition reimbursement, but they only award it to some of its employees. Even if you meet all the qualifications (approved program, employee in good standing, full-time...), you can still be turned down without being given a reason. I was turned down twice even though I met all of the qualifications. This conveys a message that education is not valued. 

4 hour push back. If the census is low, management can call you at home before your scheduled shift, and put you on a 4 hour push back. This means that you do not come in for your scheduled shift, but instead, you stay home by the phone (without pay) waiting for them to call you for up to 4 hours just in case they need you to come in on your already scheduled shift. If they dont call you, then you are officially canceled for your regularly scheduled shift.
